metadata.case_name: M/s. Chugamal Rajpal v. Income-Tax Officer

facts.text: The assessee is a partnership firm having construction contracts under the Railways as well as the Government.
For the assessment year 1960-61, relevant to the accounting year 1959-60, the assessee submitted its income-tax return.

The assessee was asked by the Income-tax Officer to produce books of account and other relevant papers, and produced a statement showing various creditors from whom it had borrowed on Hundis, giving full names and addresses.
After enquiry, the assessee's total income was assessed at Rs. 69,886/-
On June 3, 1966, the Income-tax Officer, Ward A, Muzaffarpur issued notice under s. 148 of the Income-tax Act, 1961 to the assessee.
The notice was issued after four years but before eight years of the date of the original assessment.

The assessee challenged the validity of the notice and proceedings taken on its strength on various grounds via writ petition under Arts 226 and 227 in Patna High Court (C.W.J.C. No. 952 of 1966), which was dismissed in limine on January 17, 1967.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

ITO's report dated 30-4-66 to Commissioner: Based on D.I.'s Inv. No. AP/Misc./5 D.I./63-64/5623 dated 13-8-65 and CIT letter, alleged creditors (e.g., Seth Bhagwan Singh Sricharan, Lakha Singh Lal Singh, Radhakissen Shyam Sunder) are name lenders, transactions bogus; escapement Rs. 1,00,000/-; proper investigation necessary.
Commissioner accorded satisfaction on 13-5-66 by merely writing 'Yes'.
No order sheet recording reasons of ITO as required by s. 148(2) was produced.
Appeal hearing on 18th January 1971; only ITO report and CIT order produced.

legal_issues.text: Whether the notice under s. 148 is valid, particularly compliance with s. 151(2) requiring Commissioner satisfaction on reasons recorded by ITO that it is a fit case for issue after 4 years.
Whether ITO recorded reasons for issuing notice under s. 148 and had reasons to believe under s. 147(a) or (b) that income escaped assessment.

petitioner_arguments.text: The impugned notice is invalid as it did not comply with the requirements of s. 151(2) of the Act.

court_reasoning.text: ITO's report does not set out any reason for concluding it is fit case under s. 151(2); vaguely refers to communications without mentioning facts; no prima facie conclusion that transactions bogus; only 'proper investigation necessary', which is not equivalent to reasons to believe under s. 147.
court_reasoning.key_observation: ITO had no material satisfying cl. (a) or (b) of s. 147.

court_reasoning.text: No reasons recorded by ITO as required by s. 148(2); report submitted under s. 151(2) mentions no reason for fit case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Commissioner mechanically accorded permission by just saying 'Yes' without recording satisfaction.

court_reasoning.text: Important safeguards in ss. 147 and 151 lightly treated; substituted form for substance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: ITO could not have issued notice under s. 148.

holdings.text: Notice under s. 148 invalid for non-compliance with s. 151(2); ITO must record reasons and have prima facie grounds/reasons to believe under s. 147 before issuing after 4 years, with Commissioner's satisfaction on recorded reasons.
Commissioner must record satisfaction that it is fit case, not mechanically approve.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Governing income escaping assessment, notice requirements, time limits, and Commissioner's satisfaction for notices after 4 years.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Patna High Court order set aside; impugned notice under s. 148 quashed.

key_quotes.text: "Hence proper investigation regarding these loans is necessary."
key_quotes.speaker: respondent
key_quotes.significance: Shows ITO's position was mere need for investigation, not reasons to believe escapement.

key_quotes.text: We are not satisfied that the Income-tax Officer had any material before him which could satisfy the requirements of either cl. (a) or cl. (b) of s. 147.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The important safeguards provided in sections 147 and 151 were lightly treated by the Income-tax Officer as well as by the Commissioner.
key_quotes.speaker: court
